com.navis.framework.persistence

Class HibernateApi

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.navis.framework.persistence.BaseHibernateApi
      • com.navis.framework.persistence.HibernateApi
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IHibernateDeleteApi, IDetailedDiagnostics

    public class HibernateApi
extends BaseHibernateApi
implements IHibernateDeleteApi, IDetailedDiagnostics
    Provides a wrapper for each method of Hibernate Session

    Uses the Spring framework pattern of wrapping each checked Hibernate exception with the equivalent Spring Runtime exception. All APIs(except session creation ones) assumes caller has already attached a Hibernate Session on the current thread. If you go through BizPortal, these details are handled for you. Refer to Carina docs on Persistence for more details.

    If you are an N4 application developer, you will most commonly be using api's to 1. process DomainQuery 2. entity creation/deletion

    If you are manipulating hibernating entities directly, you are required to use HibernateApi for creating and deleting. 1. For Create : when you instantiate a hibernating entity, it is in a transient state and not yet associated with a hibernate session. 2. For Delete : there is no other way to delete except through HibernateApi.delete

    When you update a hibernating entity directly, you have already loaded the entity from the session which returns it to you in a persistent state (i.e. associated with current session.). Any changes will be reflected during the flush which happens automatically during the BizRequest cycle.

    More details found in javadoc for Hibernate Session

      • findPrimaryKeys

        @Deprecated
public static java.io.Serializable[] findPrimaryKeys(DomainQuery inDq,
                                                                  UserContext inUserContext)
        Deprecated. Do NOT use this as this can cause unforeseen transactional problems. In tests you can use ManualHibernateTestCase.findCount()
        Obtains an array of primary keys specified by a DomainQuery. Can be called OUTSIDE of a Hibernate Session, as it uses the PersistenceTemplate to frame the query.

        New 2006-05-15 JJS: We are finding ourselves writing this bit of code over and over.

        Parameters:
        inDq - a DomainQuery that will select the primary keys (only needs predicates, no fields)
        inUserContext - UserContext under which the query should be executed.
        Returns:
        an array of the selected primary keys.

      • findRecapByDomainQuery

        public java.util.Map findRecapByDomainQuery(DomainQuery inDomainQuery)
        Performs a n-level 'recap', where n is the number of fields in the provided DomainQuery.
        Parameters:
        inDomainQuery - DomainQuery describing the recap. Must have at least one field.
        Returns:
        Nested Maps, where the keys at each nesting level are the fields of the DomainQuery, the innermost Map holding the count of rows matching those fields.

      • findSumRecapAsListByDomainQuery

        public java.util.List findSumRecapAsListByDomainQuery(DomainQuery inDomainQuery)
        Perform sum(field) for the recap. The sum field is assumed to be the last metafield you added to the inDomainQuery. For example, inDomainQuery.addDqField(field1); inDomainQuery.addDqField(field2); inDomainQuery.addDqField(field3); The above will be converted to HQL: select sum(field3) from table group by f1, f2.
        Parameters:
        inDomainQuery - dq
        Returns:
        Object[] of sum tables

      • findRecapAsListByDomainQuery

        public java.util.List findRecapAsListByDomainQuery(DomainQuery inDomainQuery)
        Performs a n-level 'recap', where n is the number of fields in the provided DomainQuery.
        Parameters:
        inDomainQuery - DomainQuery describing the recap. Must have at least one field.
        Returns:
        List of Object[], where size of array is n + 1(number of fields + count).

        Specified by:

      • batchUpdate

        public void batchUpdate(java.lang.String inClassName,
                        java.lang.Object[] inPrimaryKeys,
                        FieldChanges inChanges)
        Perform a batch update (new 2006-01-05 JJS). Use with caution...will not invoke any validation callbacks or the AuditInterceptor. Also, will not allow update of related entity through a compound metafield.
        Parameters:
        inClassName - class to be updated
        inPrimaryKeys - an array of primary keys of the instances to be updated
        inChanges - the fields to be updated
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified class name is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified primary key array is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified field changes are null or do not contain a field change.

      • batchInsert

        public void batchInsert(java.lang.String inClassName,

        Perform a batch insert (new 2007-02-22 JJS). Use with caution...will not invoke any validation callbacks or the AuditInterceptor. Also, will not allow update of related entity through a compound metafield.
        Parameters:
        inClassName - class to be updated
        inChanges - the fields to be updated

      • setObsoletableDeleteEnabled

        public void setObsoletableDeleteEnabled(boolean inObsoletableDeleteEnabled)
        Obsoletable objects will be permanently deleted if setting is false. The setting applies global scope and is expected to be changed only during testing. Reset back to original prior value in tests if you are changing this setting.
        Parameters:
        inObsoletableDeleteEnabled - true to enamble obsoletable
